Honest review:

Just a guy in love with his car, but has a bit of a temper problem.
 
I'd give this game a 6/10.

Story is actually not bad, it follows one decently enough. There could've been some improvements but all in all I liked it.

If you like collecting cars, you'll enjoy this. Unfortunately you can only upgrade one of them, but there is many ways to do so. Physics of driving is entertaining.

If you like Easter Egg hunting, you'll like this open world. There is plenty of things for you to find, some are actually kind of challenging.

Racing, this game has racing. In addition, you can blow up your competition if you'd like. I'd highly recommend doing so.

Crazy stunts, this game has plenty that you can do.

Fighting, its kind of boring and repetitive to me, and reminds me of Batman in that element.
The game to me seems a bit too repetitive, but on that hand its fairly stress free.

Gameplay, is challenging enough, but has harder settings if you desire.

Replayable.... ehh probably not, unless you wanna collect all the cars.

All in all its a little better than OK. 

If you like honest reviews, please hit that like button or troll me in the comments.

Mad Max has the best vehicular combat in any open world game I have played thus far. It is chaotic, action fueled and filled to the brim with explosions and charred carcasses strewn across the post-apocalyptic wasteland. The plot is not exactly the game's strong point, but it does teach us that life is often painful and disappointing and that fairy tale endings are not as common as one would like.

I highly recommend the experience.
Just buy this already. Didn't know this existed until 10 years after this came out. couldn't believe I had never heard of this amazing game. Get this game on sale it goes on sale for under ¬£2.

I wasn't really expecting much when going in, I thought it was just gonna be drive car here - fight with car - drive car there - repeat. But nah, it was an even mix of foot-walking and driving atleast for me, the story is pretty cool, but the ending was very weird.

Gameplay - driving the car was more fun then I thought, especially once you get upgrades especially the spearhook that was awesome, and the thundersticks.

Achievement-wise two achievements are bugged "Constructionist" "Up To The Task", "Constructionist" requires you to upgrade every base, which I did and it just did not pop. "Up To The Task" requires online mode , and online mode is gone. To combat those achievements use a guide on steam, where people post their save games.

Overall 9/10

I remember playing Mad Max when it first came out, and I‚Äôm still enjoying it now. The world, the vehicles, and all the chaos are just as fun as I remember. Honestly, it‚Äôs impressive how well the game holds up‚Äîit‚Äôs still a blast to play after all these years

Mad Max is like a grounded Just Cause with melee combat. it's perfect for completionists. 
Don't expect a deep story or crazy plot twists. you go through a revenge journey and simply refuse to die. 
That's it.

It's a great Mad Max simulator. Sure, it's not a perfect game but it's fun to pick up, play, and just explore the wasteland. There's plenty of respect for the source material and the vibes are perfect.

This game perfectly locks in with the vibe and flair of the latest movies and if you enjoyed these this is your game!

The graphics and the skybox is absolutely stunning and aged super well, the melancholy gets a sweet tone with carefully crafted soundtracks and history notes, love the little commentating that Max is giving about past times. Cutscenes are dope, gameplay is dope and progression is very satisfying as well. The world is surprisingly full of variation with pretty unique map tiles. The plot is alrighty too and actually dares to show consequences to a few characters that you might really start to like and thats awesome.

Of course its generic af and doing all the camps and collectibles can be really tedious and annoying but most of that is totally optional anyways.

Furthermore it ran great on my Steam Deck on which i did the playthrough and i only had a small handful of bugs and issues here and there, nothing major.

All in all a clear recommendation, its one of those nice old games that definitely dont need a remake or sequel and offer lots of fun for many years ahead!

2. Excellent Vehicle Combat
Combat behind the wheel is the game‚Äôs biggest strength.
You can ram, harpoon, blast, and rip enemy vehicles apart with satisfying physics and heavy-metal chaos. The Magnum Opus, your customizable car, becomes the heart of the experience.

3. Strong Visuals

Even years after release, the lighting, particle effects, and wide-open landscapes look great. Avalanche knows how to build stunning worlds.

4. Solid Hand-to-Hand Combat

The melee system is very similar to the Batman Arkham-style freeflow combat‚Äîsimple but impactful, with crunchy sound design.

 Where It Falls Short
1. Repetitive Gameplay Loop

Many missions boil down to clearing out enemy camps, destroying totems, or collecting scrap. The world is big, but its activities can feel copy-pasted.

2. Story Is Decent but Forgettable

While Max himself is portrayed well, the plot isn't as strong or emotional as the films. It mainly serves as a reason to drive, fight, and upgrade your car.

3. Side Content Overload

Some players feel that the game leans too heavily on open-world ‚Äúbusywork.‚Äù If you enjoy completionism, it‚Äôs fine‚Äîotherwise, it can get tedious.

My Overall Verdict

Mad Max is a flawed but underrated gem.
If you love car combat, gritty post-apocalyptic worlds, and cinematic brutality, it‚Äôs absolutely worth playing. The moment-to-moment action‚Äîespecially vehicular battles‚Äîmakes up for its repetitive structure.
 Final Score: 7.5/10

Mad Max is a good game. The combat is brutal and the graphics are amazing. The car battles and racing are fun and definitely the highlights. The ability to upgrade your skills, car, and strongholds ‚Äî along with a solid story and a tragic ending ‚Äî kept me engaged for many hours. I also love the storms; they add real tension to the world.
However, the map is too huge for a desert environment. Sometimes you spend long periods driving alone from one location to another, with no music and very few enemies, which makes the game feel empty and boring. Once you unlock all the skills and learn the fighting patterns, the combat becomes very easy. The minefields are the worst: deactivating mines takes too long, becomes repetitive, and slows the game down.
It took me many hours to complete the main campaign and all the side missions, and to explore most of the map. I left only a few locations without scavenging and a few minefields undeactivated. I also didn‚Äôt complete the car collection or the history relics. Additionally, due to its age, the game no longer has online features.
In summary, it‚Äôs not one of my favorite games, but I still like it. I‚Äôd give it a 6/10. It‚Äôs worth trying, especially if you focus mainly on the campaign.

I really loved this game. It‚Äôs so unique and you can clearly tell that the developers put some serious time and love into it. Nothing is half-assed about this game; the attention to detail in every corner of the world is astounding. The environmental storytelling is amazing. No soulless autogenerated landscape here (looking at you Starfield). Every loot location tells a story, and every place is its own thing. I feel like the Wasteland is this game‚Äôs great strength. The embracing of the emptiness that sets such a vibe is why you want to spend so many hours driving around and explore this beautiful desert. 

Your car is basically your horse and upgrading it is so satisfying. The same goes for Max, which is a freaking unit. The combat is chefs kiss, period. I love how the game manages to capture the feeling of Fury Road and still be its own thing. The game is so underrated in many aspects. Sure, the grind in this game is no joke but at least the game tries to make you truly enjoy your time. The story is not much to brag about either but it gets the job done I think *spoiler* (RIP Chumbucket though). The charm lies in the vehicular combat and the weight and grittiness of it all. Everything you do feels meaningful and like it has an impact. 

This is far from a perfect game and certainly not for everyone but it is something truly special and I don‚Äôt think there is anything else like it.  - The upgrade system is straightforward, and you can immediately see the difference. Some fighting skills are mostly for fun, but most of them are pretty useful.

 - There are tons of camps to invade, and they all have completely different designs. The side quests are so good that I kind of broke the game by doing a ton of them before the main missions. As a result, many challenging missions became quite easy for me.

 - The story isn‚Äôt a Kojima-level masterpiece, but it has a nice, simple, and dark tone.

A fine game, though it does fall into the same trappings many open world games suffer from. There are quite a few bright aspects that kept me playing however. 

The devs 100% nailed the atmosphere and feel of the Mad Max universe, at times I just drove the car around the wasteland just soaking in the world. Speaking of cars, the customisation for the Magnum Opus is really extensive. You change parts such as the engine, exhaust or even the entire body of the car. 

Vehicle combat is simple but fun, going around blowing up and ramming into War Boys never got old. Same can't be said for on foot sadly, it's the standard fair you see in Shadow Of Mordor or Assassins creed; meaning just beat the bad guys to death and make sure to counter hear and there. 

The story is an oddity, it felt focused for the first three acts but then felt muddled and abrupt in the final two acts. Plot threads felt tied up way too quickly and before I knew it the credits were rolling. 

Despite these issues, the game is still worth buying if you just want to play an fun but basic open world title. Though if you're a Mad Max fan, you'll find a lot more enjoyment in exploring the wasteland.

The premise is simple, but it is turned into a tragic yet captivating story. 

Combat is gritty and satisfying, both on foot and behind the wheel. The car mechanics specially shine. Driving through a storm with thunder cracking around you is pure adrenaline.

The world might seem empty, but it never feels pointless. It‚Äôs haunting, lonely, and beautiful with lots of side quests to do, tho after awhile some of them do feel repetitive.

But this is a wasteland that somehow pulls you in. Mad Max is one of those games that stays with you long after you‚Äôve turned off the engine.

[h2] An okay open world game with an apocalyptic setting, but unfortunately nothing more than that! [/h2]

[h3] Stability and Port [/h3]

Stability/Bugs: In times of games with disastrous conditions, it's all the better to see that Mad Max has really done a good job here. There were no crashes or game breakers. Various elements of the game interface disappeared temporarily for no apparent reason. However, these reappeared every time the game was restarted.

Port: In terms of options, graphics (which look very good), and performance, an excellent port has been delivered here. Unfortunately, some annoying aspects still remain, such as intro sequences that cannot be skipped and unnecessary double assignments on the keyboard (particularly annoying: refueling with/igniting a gas can).

[h3] The gameplay [/h3]

When you're driving around in your car and chasing a convoy, for example, the game is a lot of fun. Thanks to a range of customization options, every player can build their own hellish vehicle. With several weapons (e.g., a harpoon or flamethrower) and various enemy cars, the car combat is very varied and strongly reminiscent of the film  ‚ÄúFury Road.‚Äù 
Only the camera can be very distracting at times (e.g., because it focuses on exploding cars instead of showing the direction of travel). As the game progresses, the car's functionality is expanded to include several weapons (e.g., a sniper rifle). The car's good integration into the rest of the game is also worth mentioning. It is a central element, not just a means of transportation.
As is common today, all upgrades to the car and protagonist are tied to the player's level and special missions. While this makes sense for car parts (rare engines aren't found on every corner), it makes absolutely no sense for the character's appearance. Why does you have to reach level 30, for example, to unlock a dirty face with glasses and a full beard?

Unfortunately, the game is much less spectacular when played on foot. Here, a 1:1 copy of the popular Batman combat system is used. This also looks very spectacular here, but quickly becomes boring due to very few ‚Äúgadgets‚Äù and the lack of depth. 
Once again, the camera is a nuisance here, as it is too close behind Max, especially in rooms, to be able to see the majority of attacks from behind. In addition, in ‚ÄúFury‚Äù mode (where Max deals more damage and performs cinematic attacks, some of which are taken directly from wrestling), attacks cannot be blocked during some moves. 
Additional attacks can be unlocked for Max, but unfortunately, the melee combat never becomes more complex.

[h3] Story[/h3]

Well adapted to the setting, the story unfortunately leaves no more than a very average impression. Almost all of the characters have interesting aspects and potential, which unfortunately often goes unexploited. 
They serve more or less only as very transparent mechanisms to advance the predictable plot. The only character who leaves a somewhat lasting impression here is the mechanic, who accompanies the player almost constantly.

[h3] Beyond the story [/h3]

Here, the game strongly conveys the impression of having been designed according to a checklist inspired by, for example, the Tomb Raider reboot.

- Large map? - (In my opinion, the size here is perfect.)
- Camps/bases? - (Varied layout, but unfortunately always the same tasks.)
- Side quests? - (A few, but good quality.)
- Observation towers? - (Hot air balloons here.)
- Searching for/finding collectibles? - (With more than 200 hiding places (including camps), which often look similar or exactly the same, this was clearly overdone. Due to the enormous confusion of some camps, the hunt for the last artifact/symbol/scrap part can quickly become frustrating)
- Challenges? - (Similar problem as with the collectibles, too many and often a bit boring)
- Adrenaline mode? - (Called Fury mode here)
- Mini-bosses? - (Which look exactly the same except for their color and all (!) fight the same way)
-...

Overall, there is a lot of ‚Äúfiller‚Äù here, which varies greatly in quality. Not much attention was paid to variety here. Depending on how many of the tasks are completed by the player, the difficulty level of the game also changes noticeably (as more upgrades can be purchased for the car and protagonist). This cannot be adjusted! This makes the game far too easy for people who want to see everything. Casual players, on the other hand, will find it very challenging at times.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]

Fans of the films (Especially ‚ÄúFury Road‚Äù) may find this game entertaining, but the story is somewhat disappointing. The well-executed car combat is a very positive highlight. Unfortunately, this quality is not maintained in other aspects of the game. 

In the age of open-world games such as ‚ÄúThe Witcher 3,‚Äù more high-quality content is needed here in order to be even remotely competitive.
